hook: Toy gun that created real explosions using calcium carbide and water
fate: Discontinued in the mid-1950s after burn and eye injuries; never relaunched due to inherently dangerous mechanism.
summary: Post-war toy pistol that reacted calcium carbide with water to generate acetylene gas and a spark—producing a real explosion and smoke. After injury reports, it quietly disappeared from shelves by the 1950s.
overview_md: **Austin Magic Pistol** was a late-1940s/1950s toy gun that used **calcium carbide + water** to produce acetylene gas; a spark ignited it with a loud bang and smoke. It caused burns and eye injuries and faded from stores by the mid-1950s as safety norms changed.

timeline.text: Introduced in the post-war toy market.
Injury reports (burns/eye injuries) accumulate amid chemistry-toy craze.
Production/distribution tapers off; toy disappears from shelves.
CPSC established; concept later regarded as inherently hazardous.
